properties.name: Identify the Twitter/X Post
properties.description: First, you need the URL or the unique identifier of the Twitter/X post you want to track. This is usually found in the format https://twitter.com/user/status/post_id.

properties.name: Use the Wikipedia API
properties.description: Wikipedia has an API that allows you to query page revisions and extract references. You can use the action=query and prop=revisions parameters to get the revisions of a specific page. You can filter the revisions by date to focus on the last June 2023 versions.

properties.name: Check Page Revisions
properties.description: For each Wikipedia page you are interested in, you can retrieve the revisions for the specific date range (e.g., all revisions in June 2023). You can use the rvstart and rvend parameters to specify the date range.

properties.name: Extract References
properties.description: Once you have the revisions, you can extract the text of each revision and look for the specific Twitter/X post URL. You can use regular expressions or string matching to find occurrences of the Twitter/X post in the reference list.

properties.name: Count Citations
properties.description: For each day in August, you can maintain a count of how many times the Twitter/X post was cited in the revisions from June 2023. You may need to repeat this process for each relevant Wikipedia page.

properties.name: Automate the Process
properties.description: If you are comfortable with programming, you can write a script (in Python, for example) to automate the API calls, extract the revisions, and count the citations.

properties.name: Manual Search
properties.description: If you prefer a manual approach, you can also use the View History feature on Wikipedia pages to look through revisions, but this is less efficient for large-scale tracking.

By combining the Wikipedia API with some programming or manual searching, you can effectively track how many times a specific Twitter/X post was cited on Wikipedia pages during the specified time frame.

properties.name: Identify the Twitter/X Post
properties.description: Get the URL of the Twitter/X Post: Make sure you have the specific URL of the Twitter/X post you want to track. For example, it might look like this: https://twitter.com/username/status/1234567890123456789.

properties.name: Set Up Your Environment
properties.description: Install Required Libraries: If you are using Python, you may want to install the requests library to make API calls. You can do this using pip: pip install requests.

properties.name: Use the Wikipedia API
properties.description: Access the Wikipedia API: Wikipedia provides a RESTful API that you can use to query page content. The base URL for the API is: https://en.wikipedia.org/w/api.php.

properties.name: Get the List of Pages
properties.description: You may want to start by getting a list of relevant Wikipedia pages. You can use the search endpoint to find pages related to your topic of interest.

properties.name: Retrieve Page Revisions
properties.description: Get Page Revisions: For each page, you will need to get the revisions from June 2023. You can do this using the revisions endpoint.

properties.name: Search for Twitter/X Post References
properties.description: Search for References: For each revision, check if it contains a reference to the Twitter/X post. You can do this by checking if the content includes the URL of the post.

properties.name: Count References for Each Day in August
properties.description: Get Daily Counts: To count references for each day in August, you will need to repeat the process for each day in August 2023.

properties.name: Analyze and Store Results
properties.description: Store Results: You can store the results in a CSV file or a database for further analysis.

By following these steps, you can extract citation data for a specific Twitter/X post from English Wikipedia pages, focusing on the June 2023 versions and counting references for each day in August 2023.

properties.name: Identify the Wikipedia API Endpoint
properties.description: The main endpoint for querying the Wikipedia API is: https://en.wikipedia.org/w/api.php

properties.name: Query Page Revisions
properties.description: To get the revisions of a specific page, you can use the revisions action. You will need to specify the page title and the properties you want to retrieve.

properties.name: Example API Request
properties.description: Here’s an example of how to query the revisions of a specific page (e.g., "Example_Page") for June 2023: https://en.wikipedia.org/w/api.php?action=query&titles=Example_Page&prop=revisions&rvstart=2023-06-01T00:00:00Z&rvend=2023-06-30T23:59:59Z&rvprop=content|timestamp|user&format=json

properties.name: Parameters Explained
properties.description: This section explains the parameters used in the API request.

properties.description: Once you have the content of the revisions, you can parse the text to find references to Twitter/X posts.

properties.name: Example Regular Expression in Python
properties.description: Here’s a simple example of how you might extract Twitter/X links from the revision content using Python.
